Massages internal organs aiding digestion. Helps manage minor back stiffness. Those suffering from severe back pain, vertebral disorders, disc problems, or women during menstruation should avoid this practice. The twisting motion should come from the core, not by forcing shoulders or arms.
precautions: Precautions: Cardiac patients should proceed with care and avoid holding breath.

title: Knee Movement Practice for Joint Strength
source: Common Yoga Protocol - Ministry of Ayush, Government of India
info: Knee movements strengthen lower body and prepare legs for standing poses. Starting position: Samasthiti with feet together. Inhale and lift both arms forward to shoulder level, keeping palms facing down. Exhale and bend both knees to create a semi-squat position, ensuring thighs become parallel to the ground. Keep heels on the floor and back relatively straight. Inhale and straighten body, returning to standing position. Repeat the sequence 2 more rounds, maintaining awareness of knee alignment. Benefits: Strengthens knee joints and surrounding muscles. Improves flexibility in hip joints. Builds leg strength essential for standing postures. Enhances balance and stability. If experiencing knee pain, reduce the depth of the squat or skip the practice. Ensure knees track over toes and don't collapse inward. This simple movement prepares the body for more complex standing asanas and helps prevent knee injuries during practice.
precautions: Precautions: Those suffering from acute arthritis should avoid this practice.

title: Tadasana - Palm Tree Posture Complete Instructions
source: Common Yoga Protocol - Ministry of Ayush, Government of India
info: Tadasana is the foundation of all standing postures. Starting position: Samasthiti with feet approximately 2 inches apart. Inhale and lift both arms to shoulder level. Interlock the fingers and turn wrists outward so palms face away. Continue inhaling and raise arms above the head, keeping them straight. Simultaneously lift heels off the ground and balance on toes. Maintain this position for 10-30 seconds while breathing normally and keeping body steady. Exhale and slowly lower heels to ground, release hands, and bring arms down to sides. Benefits: Develops stability and firmness of body and mind. Clears spinal nerve congestion by stretching entire spine. Corrects faulty posture by strengthening postural muscles. Improves balance and body awareness. Stretches abdomen preventing sagging. Those with varicose veins or vertigo should practice without heel raise. Practice near wall for support if balance is challenging. Despite its simplicity, Tadasana teaches proper alignment and grounding essential for all yoga practices.
precautions: Precautions: Those suffering from arthritis should avoid lifting heels.

title: Pada Hastasana - Hands to Feet Posture Detailed Guide
source: Common Yoga Protocol - Ministry of Ayush, Government of India
info: Pada Hastasana is an intense forward bend with numerous benefits. Starting position: Samasthiti. Inhale and raise both arms upward, stretching the entire body from the waist. Exhale and bend forward from the hips until palms rest on the ground beside the feet. If unable to touch ground, bend only as far as comfortable. Stretch the back to make it as straight as possible in the forward fold. Hold the position for 10-30 seconds, breathing naturally. Inhale and slowly come up, raising arms overhead. Exhale and return arms to sides. Benefits: Creates a flexible and supple spine. Improves digestion by massaging abdominal organs. Helps alleviate menstrual problems in women. Stretches hamstrings and back muscles. Improves blood circulation to head and face. Those with stiff back should bend only to their capacity - touching knees or shins is acceptable. Never force the body beyond its present flexibility. Regular practice gradually increases forward bending ability.
precautions: Precautions: Avoid if suffering from cardiac disorders, vertebral or disc disorders, abdominal inflammation, hernia, peptic ulcers, glaucoma, myopia, vertigo. Avoid if suffering from cardiac disorders, vertebral or disc disorders, abdominal inflammation, hernia, peptic ulcers, glaucoma, myopia, vertigo.

title: Ardhachakrasana - Half Wheel Posture for Back Flexibility
source: Common Yoga Protocol - Ministry of Ayush, Government of India
info: Ardhachakrasana is a standing backward bend that strengthens the spine. Starting position: Samasthiti. Place both hands on the back at waist level with fingers pointing downward for support. Inhale and drop head backward gently, looking up and back. Exhale and bend backward slowly from the lumbar (lower back) region, using hands for support. The bend should be gradual and controlled, coming mainly from the lower back. Hold the position for 10-30 seconds while breathing normally. Inhale and slowly come back to upright position, head coming up last. Benefits: Creates flexibility in the spine, particularly in the lumbar region. Strengthens spinal nerves and muscles. Helps manage cervical spondylosis. Opens chest and improves breathing. Strengthens back muscles preventing slouching. Hypertensive patients should bend backward with great care and only minimally. Never force backward bend. Start with small movements and gradually increase range. Always support lower back with hands to prevent strain. This pose counteracts the forward-bent posture many people maintain throughout the day.
precautions: Precautions: Those suffering from vertigo or giddiness should avoid this practice.

title: Trikonasana - Triangle Posture Complete Technique
source: Common Yoga Protocol - Ministry of Ayush, Government of India
info: Trikonasana is a fundamental standing pose with lateral bending. Starting position: Samasthiti with feet approximately 3 feet apart. Inhale and raise both arms sideways to shoulder level, palms facing down. Turn right foot completely to the right at 90 degrees. Exhale and bend body to the right side, placing right hand behind the right foot on the ground. If unable to reach ground, place hand on ankle or shin. Left arm extends straight up in line with right arm, creating one straight line from left hand to right hand. Turn head to gaze at the left middle finger. Hold position for 10-30 seconds, breathing normally. Inhale and come up to standing. Repeat entire sequence on the left side. Benefits: Creates flexibility in the spine through lateral bending. Strengthens calf muscles, thighs, and waist. Improves lung capacity. Massages and tones abdominal organs. Do not over-stretch - if feet are too far apart, bring them closer or touch knee instead of foot. Those with neck problems should look forward instead of up.
precautions: Precautions: Avoid for slipped disc, sciatica, or after recent abdominal surgery.

title: Vajrasana - Thunderbolt Posture for Meditation and Digestion
source: Common Yoga Protocol - Ministry of Ayush, Government of India
info: Vajrasana is a stable kneeling posture with unique digestive benefits. Starting from Virmsana (long sitting), fold both legs under the buttocks. Big toes should touch each other while heels remain apart, creating a space for buttocks to rest in between the heels. Rest both hands on the knees, palms facing down. Keep spine completely erect, head and neck straight. Eyes may be open or closed. Hold position for 10-30 seconds initially, gradually increasing duration. Benefits: Unique among asanas as it can be practiced immediately after eating - it aids digestion. Strengthens thigh and calf muscles. Improves blood circulation in pelvic region. Reduces fat around belly. Helps alleviate digestive disorders. Provides stable base for meditation and pranayama. If ankles hurt, place soft cloth under them. Regular practice gradually increases flexibility making the pose more comfortable. Vajra means thunderbolt, indicating the strength and stability this pose creates.
precautions: Precautions: Those suffering from piles, knee pain, ankle injury, or severe arthritis should avoid.

title: Ustrasana - Camel Posture for Heart and Spine
source: Common Yoga Protocol - Ministry of Ayush, Government of India
info: Ustrasana is an intense backward bending posture performed from kneeling. Starting from Vajrasana, stand on the knees with feet slightly apart. Inhale and arch backward, placing both palms on respective heels. Exhale and ensure thighs are vertical to the ground while head drops back comfortably. Chest pushes forward and upward creating maximum arch in the back. Hold position for 10-30 seconds with normal breathing. To release, slowly come up by removing hands from heels one at a time. Benefits: Helps correct defective eyesight by improving blood circulation to eyes. Relieves back and neck pain by strengthening spinal muscles. Reduces abdominal fat through compression and stretching of abdomen. Improves digestion by massaging abdominal organs. Enhances cardio-respiratory function by opening chest. Stimulates thyroid gland. Increases flexibility of entire spine. Those with high blood pressure should practice only under expert supervision. Pregnant women should avoid. Never force into the full pose - progress gradually over weeks and months of regular practice.
precautions: Precautions: Those with heart disease or hernia should strictly avoid.

title: Vakrasana - Spinal Twist Posture for Detoxification
source: Common Yoga Protocol - Ministry of Ayush, Government of India
info: Vakrasana, also known as Marchysana, is a seated spinal twist with cleansing properties. Starting from Dandsana (staff pose with legs extended), bend the right leg and place right foot flat beside the left knee. Twist torso to the right. Bring left arm around the outside of right knee, clasping the right big toe or placing palm on floor near right hip. Place right hand on the floor behind the body, fingers pointing back. Exhale and twist further to the right, looking over right shoulder. Hold 10-30 seconds, breathing normally. Release and repeat on opposite side. Benefits: Creates excellent flexibility in the spine through rotation. Stimulates pancreas, making it beneficial for diabetes management. Massages abdominal organs improving digestion. Relieves constipation. Strengthens oblique muscles. Improves liver and spleen function. Detoxifies body by wringing out spine like a wet towel. Women should avoid during menstruation. Always twist from the belly, not just shoulders. Keep spine elongated throughout the twist - never collapse or compress the spine.
precautions: Precautions: Avoid for acute back pain, spinal disorders, or recent abdominal surgery.

title: Bhujangasana - Cobra Posture Comprehensive Guide
source: Common Yoga Protocol - Ministry of Ayush, Government of India
info: Bhujangasana is a foundational prone backbend resembling a cobra raising its hood. Starting from Makarsana (crocodile pose), bring legs together with feet touching. Place hands beside chest, palms down, elbows raised and close to body. Inhale and slowly lift head, neck, and chest using back strength primarily, not pushing heavily with arms. Lift chest up to navel region, keeping navel on ground. Draw shoulders back and down, opening chest. Look upward gently without straining neck. Hold 10-30 seconds, breathing normally. Exhale and slowly lower chest, then head. Benefits: Relieves stress and fatigue by opening chest and heart. Alleviates constipation through abdominal massage. Reduces abdominal fat. Helpful for backache by strengthening back muscles. Beneficial for bronchial problems and asthma by expanding lungs. Stimulates abdominal organs. Improves blood circulation to spine. Those with hernia, peptic ulcers, or hyperthyroid should not practice. Pregnant women should avoid. The lift should come from back strength, not arm strength - this is key to gaining benefit without strain.
precautions: Precautions: Avoid for 2-3 months after abdominal surgery.

title: Shalabhasana - Locust Posture for Lower Body Strength
source: Common Yoga Protocol - Ministry of Ayush, Government of India
info: Shalabhasana strengthens the entire posterior chain of the body. Starting from Makarsana, place chin on floor instead of forehead. Straighten arms and place them beside the body, palms facing down or in fists. Legs remain straight and together. Inhale deeply and raise both legs off the ground without bending knees, lifting as high as comfortably possible. Keep chin firmly on floor for leverage. Hold position 10-30 seconds while breathing naturally. Exhale and slowly lower legs. Benefits: Excellent for sciatica and lower backache. Reduces fat around thighs and buttocks. Significantly improves lung capacity. Strengthens back, hip, and leg muscles. Tones abdominal organs. Improves digestion. Helps correct postural defects. Avoid entirely for high blood pressure, peptic ulcer, or hernia. Pregnant women should not practice. The lift should be smooth and controlled - avoid jerky movements. This challenging pose builds both strength and endurance when practiced regularly.
precautions: Precautions: Those with severe lower back pain should practice with caution, perhaps lifting one leg at a time.

title: Setubandhasana - Bridge Posture for Back Health
source: Common Yoga Protocol - Ministry of Ayush, Government of India
info: Setubandhasana creates a bridge shape with the body, offering multiple benefits. Starting from avsana (corpse pose), bend both knees and bring heels close to buttocks, feet flat on floor hip-width apart. Hold ankles with respective hands, or keep arms beside body. Inhale and raise buttocks and trunk off the ground, creating a bridge shape with the body. Only shoulders, head, feet, and arms remain on ground. Push hips up as high as comfortable. Hold 10-30 seconds, breathing normally. Exhale and slowly lower back down, vertebra by vertebra. Benefits: Helps alleviate depression and anxiety by opening heart center. Strengthens lower back muscles. Improves digestion by massaging abdominal organs. Stretches chest, neck, and spine. Therapeutic for mild backache. Reduces stress and fatigue. Stimulates thyroid, lungs, and abdominal organs. Those with neck injuries should practice only under expert guidance or avoid. This pose can be practiced by placing a block under sacrum for a more restorative version. Regular practice strengthens entire posterior chain of body.
precautions: Precautions: Avoid for ulcer or hernia.

title: Pavanamuktasana - Wind Releasing Posture for Digestive Health
source: Common Yoga Protocol - Ministry of Ayush, Government of India
info: Pavanamuktasana specifically targets digestive issues and intestinal health. Starting from avsana, bend both knees and bring them toward chest. Clasp arms around shins, hugging knees close to body. Exhale and raise head off ground, bringing chin toward knees or touching forehead to knees if possible. Entire spine should curl up in a compact position. Hold 10-30 seconds while breathing normally, feeling compression on abdomen. Release head first, then arms, and gently lower legs. Benefits: Highly effective for constipation and flatulence. Releases trapped gas from intestines. Improves overall digestion. Strengthens abdominal muscles. Massages entire abdominal region. Strengthens spinal nerves. Tones muscles of arms and legs. Reduces fat around buttocks and thighs. The compression on abdomen makes this pose very powerful for digestive issues but also means it must be avoided when abdomen is vulnerable. The name Pavana means wind and Mukta means release, perfectly describing its primary function.
precautions: Precautions: Strictly avoid for abdominal injuries, hernia, sciatica, severe back pain, slipped disc, or during pregnancy.

title: Shavasana - Corpse Posture for Complete Relaxation
source: Common Yoga Protocol - Ministry of Ayush, Government of India
info: Shavasana is the ultimate relaxation pose, concluding every yoga practice. Lie flat on back in supine position. Place arms and legs slightly apart from body for comfort - arms about 15 degrees from torso, legs comfortably separated. Turn palms facing upward in receptive position. Close eyes gently. Consciously relax every part of body starting from toes and moving upward through legs, abdomen, chest, arms, shoulders, neck, face, and head. Relax facial muscles especially - forehead, eyes, jaw. Breathe slowly and shallowly, allowing breath to become very subtle. Let go of all physical and mental tension. Remain in complete stillness for 5-15 minutes. To come out, gently deepen breath, move fingers and toes, stretch arms overhead, roll to right side, and slowly sit up. Benefits: Relieves overall bodily tension and mental stress. Activates parasympathetic nervous system promoting rest and healing. Lowers blood pressure and heart rate. Allows integration of practice benefits. Essential for stress management. Despite appearing simple, Shavasana is considered one of the most challenging poses because the mind resists complete stillness. Yet it is also one of the most important practices in yoga.
precautions: Practice under guidance if you are a beginner. Stop if you experience pain or discomfort.

title: Kapalabhati - Frontal Brain Cleansing Breath Detailed
source: Common Yoga Protocol - Ministry of Ayush, Government of India
info: Kapalabhati is a powerful cleansing breath technique that purifies the respiratory system. Sit in any comfortable meditative posture with spine erect. Take a deep inhalation to prepare. Then forcefully expel breath through both nostrils using rapid contraction of abdominal muscles. The exhalation should be short, quick, and forceful. Inhalation between exhalations is passive and automatic - simply release the abdomen and air flows in naturally. Focus entirely on forceful exhalations. Count 30 rapid breaths to complete one round. Take a break with normal breathing between rounds. Practice total of 3 rounds, gradually increasing count to 60 per round with regular practice. Benefits: Purifies frontal sinuses and entire nasal passage. Excellent for cough, asthma, sinusitis, allergies. Rejuvenates entire body by increasing oxygen supply. Strengthens abdominal muscles and diaphragm. Improves digestion. Increases concentration and mental clarity. Removes toxins from blood. Stop immediately if feeling dizzy. This is a heating, energizing practice best done in morning. Kapalabhati means skull shining, referring to the clarity it brings to mind.
precautions: Precautions: Strictly avoid for cardiac conditions, high blood pressure, vertigo, hernia, gastric ulcer, pregnancy, menstruation, stroke, epilepsy.

title: Nadi Shodhana - Alternate Nostril Breathing Complete Technique
source: Common Yoga Protocol - Ministry of Ayush, Government of India
info: Nadi Shodhana, also called Anuloma Viloma, purifies energy channels and balances brain hemispheres. Sit in comfortable meditative posture with spine erect. Place left hand in Jnana Mudra on left knee (index finger and thumb touching). Form Nasagra Mudra with right hand: fold index and middle fingers toward palm, using thumb to close right nostril and ring finger to close left nostril. Close right nostril with thumb and inhale slowly through left nostril. At end of inhalation, close left nostril with ring finger and release thumb to exhale through right nostril. Immediately inhale through right nostril. Close right nostril and exhale through left. This completes one full round. Continue for 5 rounds initially, gradually increasing to 10-15 minutes. Initially maintain equal duration for inhalation and exhalation. With practice, gradually establish 1:2 ratio (exhalation twice as long as inhalation). Benefits: Creates profound tranquility and improves concentration. Excellent for managing stress and anxiety. Balances left (logical) and right (creative) brain hemispheres. Purifies nadis (energy channels). Prepares mind perfectly for meditation. This is one of the safest and most beneficial pranayama practices suitable for almost everyone.
precautions: Practice under guidance if you are a beginner. Stop if you experience pain or discomfort.

title: Shitali Pranayama - Cooling Breath for Heat Management
source: Common Yoga Protocol - Ministry of Ayush, Government of India
info: Shitali Pranayama is a cooling breath technique that reduces internal heat. Sit in Padmsana or any comfortable meditative posture. Roll tongue lengthwise into a tube shape, extending tongue slightly beyond lips. If unable to roll tongue (genetic trait), form 'O' shape with lips. Inhale slowly and deeply through the rolled tongue or pursed lips, feeling cool air flow in. After complete inhalation, close mouth and exhale slowly through both nostrils. This completes one round. Repeat for 5 rounds initially, gradually increasing duration. Benefits: Powerfully cools body and mind, making it ideal for hot weather or after heating practices. Beneficial for high blood pressure. Quenches thirst more effectively than drinking water. Improves digestion and reduces acidity. Reduces inflammation in body. Purifies blood. Calms nervous system. Not suitable for practice in very cold weather. This practice demonstrates yoga's sophisticated understanding of breath's ability to regulate body temperature and internal states. The name Shitali means cooling, perfectly describing the technique's primary effect.
precautions: Precautions: Avoid for severe cold, cough, tonsillitis, or respiratory infections.

title: Dhyana - Meditation Practice for Inner Peace
source: Common Yoga Protocol - Ministry of Ayush, Government of India
info: Dhyana or meditation is the pinnacle of yoga practice, leading to self-realization. Sit in meditation posture - Padmasana, Sukhasana, or any comfortable cross-legged position with spine naturally erect. Form Dhyana Mudra with hands: rest hands in lap, right hand on left, palms facing up, thumbs lightly touching. Close eyes and direct inner gaze toward space between eyebrows (Ajna chakra). Begin by observing thoughts without judgment or engagement. Gradually allow thoughts to dissolve, creating gaps of pure awareness between thoughts. Eventually attain state of single pure thought or thoughtless awareness. Start with 5-10 minutes and gradually increase duration. Benefits: Eliminates negative emotions like anger, fear, greed, and jealousy. Dramatically improves concentration and memory. Strengthens willpower and determination. Reduces stress, anxiety, and depression. Enhances creativity and problem-solving. Creates profound inner peace. Improves overall mental health and emotional stability. Regular practice leads to self-knowledge and spiritual awakening. Meditation is not about stopping thoughts forcefully but about developing witness consciousness - the ability to observe mind without being controlled by it. This is the essence of yoga.
precautions: Practice under guidance if you are a beginner. Stop if you experience pain or discomfort.

title: Sankalpa - Positive Resolve for Personal Growth
source: Common Yoga Protocol - Ministry of Ayush, Government of India
info: Sankalpa is a positive resolve or intention stated at the conclusion of practice to embed its benefits in daily life. After completing asanas, pranayama, and meditation, while still in a relaxed and receptive state, silently state your Sankalpa. The Common Yoga Protocol recommends this Sankalpa: I commit myself to maintaining a balanced state of mind at all times. It is in this state that my growth reaches its fullest potential. I pledge to fulfill my responsibilities to myself, family, work, society, and the world to promote peace, health, and harmony. A Sankalpa should be: Brief and clear, stated in present tense as if already true, emotionally resonant and meaningful to you personally, repeated consistently. The deep relaxation after practice makes the mind highly receptive to positive suggestions. Regular practice of Sankalpa creates profound changes by aligning subconscious mind with conscious goals. This ancient technique recognizes that true change begins in the mind and radiates outward into actions and life circumstances. Sankalpa plants seeds of transformation that grow through consistent practice.
precautions: Practice under guidance if you are a beginner. Stop if you experience pain or discomfort.

title: Shanti Patha - Peace Invocation for Universal Wellbeing
source: Common Yoga Protocol - Ministry of Ayush, Government of India
info: Shanti Patha or Peace Chant concludes yoga practice by extending wishes of wellbeing to all beings. After Sankalpa, chant or silently repeat: Om Sarve Bhavantu Sukhina, Sarve Santu Nirmay. Sarve Bhadri Payantu, M kacit Dukha Bhgbhavet. Om nti nti nti. Translation: May All become Happy, May All be Free from Illness. May All See what is Auspicious, May No One Suffer. Om Peace, Peace, Peace. The three repetitions of Shanti represent peace in three dimensions: Adhibhautika (peace with external world and other beings), Adhidaivika (peace with forces of nature and divine), Adhyatmika (inner peace within oneself). This chant embodies yoga's fundamental principle that individual wellbeing is interconnected with universal wellbeing. By wishing happiness and freedom from suffering for all beings, we transcend ego boundaries and align with highest yogic ideals of compassion and unity. Regular practice of this chant cultivates genuine benevolence and reminds us that our practice serves not just personal goals but contributes to collective peace and harmony. This is the true spirit of yoga.
precautions: Practice under guidance if you are a beginner. Stop if you experience pain or discomfort.

title: Yoga During Pregnancy - Safe Practices and Modifications
source: Common Yoga Protocol - Ministry of Ayush, Government of India
info: Pregnancy requires special considerations for yoga practice. General guidelines: Always practice under guidance of qualified prenatal yoga instructor. Consult doctor before beginning or continuing practice. Listen to body and never force or strain. Safe practices during pregnancy: Gentle breathing exercises (avoid breath retention), Pelvic floor exercises, Cat-Cow stretches, Modified standing poses with wall support, Gentle hip openers like Bhadrasana, Supported resting poses. Practices to AVOID during pregnancy: All inversions including headstand and shoulder stand, Deep twists especially closed twists, Strong backbends, Poses lying on belly after first trimester, Poses lying flat on back after second trimester, Breath retention (Kumbhaka), Kapalabhati and Bhastrika, Deep forward bends that compress abdomen, Jumping or jerky movements. Benefits of safe prenatal yoga: Prepares body for childbirth, Strengthens pelvic floor, Reduces back pain, Improves circulation, Reduces stress and anxiety, Promotes better sleep, Helps maintain healthy weight. Each trimester has different needs - first trimester requires extra caution, second trimester allows more activity, third trimester needs maximum modification. Always inform instructor about pregnancy stage and any complications.
precautions: Consult a healthcare provider before practicing if you have any medical conditions.

title: Yoga with High Blood Pressure - Safe Practice Guidelines
source: Common Yoga Protocol - Ministry of Ayush, Government of India
info: High blood pressure (hypertension) requires careful yoga practice with specific modifications. Safe practices for hypertension: Gentle forward bends (seated, not standing), Supported resting poses like Shavasana, Legs-up-the-wall with support, Gentle twists, Slow deep breathing, Alternate nostril breathing, Meditation and relaxation techniques. Practices to AVOID with high blood pressure: All inversions (headstand, shoulder stand, downward dog held long), Breath retention, especially after inhalation, Kapalabhati and Bhastrika pranayama, Intense backbends, Holding poses for long duration, Any practice that causes strain or breathlessness, Competitive or goal-oriented practice. Important Benefits when practiced correctly: Reduces stress which elevates blood pressure, Improves cardiovascular health, Enhances relaxation response, May reduce medication needs over time (under medical supervision), Improves overall quality of life. Yoga should complement, not replace, medical treatment for hypertension.
precautions: precautions: Practice only when blood pressure is under control with medication, Never stop medication without doctor consultation, Monitor blood pressure regularly, Inform yoga teacher about condition, Stop immediately if feeling dizzy, lightheaded, or having headache, Avoid early morning practice if BP is poorly controlled.

title: Yoga with Heart Conditions - Essential Safety Precautions
source: Common Yoga Protocol - Ministry of Ayush, Government of India
info: Cardiac conditions require extra caution and medical clearance for yoga practice. Essential Safe practices with cardiac conditions: Gentle breathing exercises without retention, Slow movements with emphasis on exhalation, Supported relaxation poses, Gentle stretches, Meditation and visualization, Shavasana with upper body elevated if needed. Practices to STRICTLY AVOID: All inversions, Breath retention (Kumbhaka), Intense physical poses, Valsalva maneuver (bearing down), Kapalabhati and Bhastrika, Intense backbends, Any practice causing strain or breathlessness, Competitive practice, Hot yoga or heated rooms. Specific conditions require specific approaches: Recent heart attack - wait minimum 6 months, under cardiologist supervision, Angina - extremely gentle practice only, Heart failure - consult cardiologist, may need oxygen monitoring, Arrhythmias - avoid stimulating practices. Benefits when practiced safely: Reduces stress on heart, Improves circulation gently, Enhances parasympathetic tone, Supports cardiac rehabilitation, Improves quality of life. Cardiac yoga therapy programs under medical supervision show good results.
precautions: precautions: Obtain doctor's written clearance before starting, Practice only under qualified instructor experienced with cardiac conditions, Keep doctor informed about your practice, Monitor heart rate during practice, Stop immediately if experiencing chest pain, excessive breathlessness, dizziness, or irregular heartbeat.

title: Yoga with Spinal Problems - Disc Issues and Back Pain
source: Common Yoga Protocol - Ministry of Ayush, Government of India
info: Spinal disorders including herniated discs, sciatica, and chronic back pain require careful practice. Safe practices for back problems: Gentle spinal movements within pain-free range, Cat-Cow stretches (very gentle), Pelvic tilts, Knee-to-chest pose (one leg at a time), Supported Child's pose, Supine twists (gentle), Relaxation practices, Breathing exercises. Practices to AVOID with spinal problems: Deep forward bends, especially standing ones, Intense twists, Strong backbends, Inversions (depending on condition), Leg raises (if sciatica), Poses that cause pain or tingling, Any jerky movements. Specific conditions: Herniated disc - avoid all forward bends and twists initially, Sciatica - avoid forward bends, practice gentle hip openers, Spinal stenosis - avoid backbends, forward bends may feel better, Spondylolisthesis - avoid backbends and twists, Chronic lower back pain - strengthen core, gentle movements only. Important principles: Pain is a signal to stop - never push through pain, Tingling or numbness requires immediate stop, Strengthen core muscles to support spine, Start with physical therapy or yoga therapy evaluation, Progress very gradually, Be patient with healing process. Benefits of appropriate practice: Reduces pain over time, Improves flexibility carefully, Strengthens supporting muscles, Enhances body awareness, Provides pain management tools, Improves quality of life. Work with qualified yoga therapist or instructor experienced with back problems.
precautions: Practice under guidance if you are a beginner. Stop if you experience pain or discomfort.

title: Yoga During Menstruation - Traditional Guidelines and Modern Approaches
source: Common Yoga Protocol - Ministry of Ayush, Government of India
info: Menstruation requires honoring the body's natural cycle with appropriate modifications. Traditional approach: Avoid inversions during menstruation, Avoid strong abdominal work, Avoid intense backbends, Reduce overall intensity of practice, Focus on restorative and gentle practices. Reasoning behind restrictions: Inversions may interfere with natural downward flow (Apana Vayu), Intense practice may increase bleeding, Rest supports body's cleansing process. Safe practices during menstruation: Gentle forward bends (opening hips), Supported resting poses, Gentle twists, Hip openers like Bhadrasana and Butterfly, Legs-up-the-wall (though traditionally avoided as inversion, many find it helpful), Gentle breathing practices, Meditation and relaxation, Yin yoga style holds. Modern perspective: Many women practice normally during menstruation without issues, Individual experience varies greatly, Listen to your body above all rules, If feeling well, gentle inversions may be okay, If experiencing cramps, rest and restorative practice is wise. Benefits of appropriate practice during menstruation: Reduces menstrual cramps, Relieves back pain, Reduces bloating, Improves mood, Manages PMS symptoms, Promotes hormonal balance. Each woman's experience is unique - honor what your body needs. Some days may allow more active practice, other days require complete rest. Yoga teaches us to be attuned to body's changing needs.
